Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an integrated atomic force microscope/ Inverted optical microscope for interdisciplinary research at Cleveland State University

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1337859
Kothapalli

The proposed instrument will support a broad range of cutting-edge and innovative research
projects spanning five disciplines (Biomedical, Chemical, Electrical, Physics and Chemistry)
at CSU. This integrated instrument is of great value to a growing core of CSU faculty
whose research portfolios encompass: novel materials for biomedical, electronics and energy
applications, biosensors, thermo-responsive polymers, nano-scale systems, biomechanics of
soft materials, and live imaging of cellular/ sub-cellular features under physiological conditions.
The projects that will benefit from extensive access to the proposed equipment include:
(i) Structural and mechanical properties of soft materials, (ii) Mechanotransduction effects
on stem cell differentiation, (iii) Characterization of chemically-selective and biocompatible-chemistry
for biomolecule, biomaterial and living-cell modifications, (iv) Design, synthesis and evaluation
of cell-surface mimetic molecules for biomedical applications, (v) Characterization of functional
molecular building blocks for responsive materials, (vi) Image analysis of primary cilium
in living cells, (vii) Characterization of hybrid strategies for fabrication of nanostructured
arrays, (viii) Characterization of nano-textured metallic substrates for bone tissue engineering,
(ix) Investigation of nano-porous anodized alumina templates and membranes for hydrogen storage,
and (x) Improving the stability of immobilized enzymes for bioelectronic applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With funding from NSF, under the MRI grant mechanism, Cleveland State University acquired and installed an integrated research equipment consisting of a MFP-3D-BIO atomic force microscope (Asylum Research Inc, Santa Barbara, CA) together with an inverted Nikon Eclipse Ti-U microscope. Since its installation in Summer 2014, we have established and optimized numerous protocols for investigating the physical and mechanical properties of various materials and biological specimens. This equipment has been supporting a broad range of cutting edge research projects in multiple disciplines (Chemical, Mechanical, Physics, Chemistry, Electrical Engineering, Biomedical) within two colleges at CSU (Engineering, Sciences), Cleveland Clinic Biomedical Engineering department, and local industry. Recent projects which benefitted from acquisition of this instrument include, characterization of biomedical grade materials, biosensors, thermoresponsive polymers, drug-loaded liposomes, nanoparticulate systems, biomechanics of soft materials such as gels and tissues, cell biomechanics, thin-flim characterization, live-imaging of cells, characterization of subcellular features, etc. Over the past two years, dozens of undergradute and graduate students in engineering, physics, chemistry and biology have gained valuable training and research experience each semester, either by directly involving in the proposed research projects, or through enrollment in various credit-bearing courses (e.g., Biomechanics, Biomaterials, Tissue Engineering). Many junior faculty at CSU have also been trained and provided access to this equipment so that they can generate results for advancing their career - proposal submission to external funding agencies, journal publications, conference presentations, etc. In summary, acquisition of this integrated equipment has been enabling us to fulfill our anticipated objectives in acquiring high-quality data needed for succesful execution of technologically-challenging projects, training undergraduate and graduate students, applying for external funding to support the research, teaching and mentoring activities at CSU.
